Scheme 1 Reaction pathway for the oxidation of HMF over the Ru/HAP catalyst. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Plausible reaction mechanism of the base-free aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA over the Ru/HAP catalyst. Scheme 2 Fig. 1 Influence of HMF/Ru molar ratio on the oxidation of HMF over the Ru/HAP catalyst. Reaction conditions: HMF, 2 mmol; H2O, 20 mL; temperature, 120 °C; time, 24 h; O2, 1 MPa. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Influence of O2 pressure on the oxidation of HMF over the Ru/HAP catalyst. Reaction conditions: HMF, 2 mmol; HMF/Ru, 25; H2O, 20 mL; temperature, 120 °C; time, 24 h. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Influence of reaction temperature on the oxidation of HMF over the Ru/HAP catalyst. Reaction conditions: HMF, 2 mmol; HMF/Ru, 25; H2O, 20 mL; time, 24 h; O2, 1 MPa. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Time course for the oxidation of HMF over the Ru/HAP catalyst. Reaction conditions: HMF, 2 mmol; HMF/Ru, 25; H2O, 20 mL; temperature, 120 °C; O2, 1 MPa. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Kinetic curves of the oxidation of HMF and its derived intermediates over the Ru/HAP catalyst. Reaction condition: substrate, 2 mmol; substrate/Ru, 50; H2O, 20 mL; O2, 1 MPa; temperature, 120 °C. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Recycling test of the Ru/HAP catalyst under (a) the optimized conditions: HMF, 2 mmol; HMF/Ru, 25; H2O, 20 mL; O2, 1 MPa; temperature, 120 °C; time, 24 h; and (b) the kinetic-controlled region: substrate, 2 mmol; substrate/Ru, 50; H2O, 20 mL; O2, 1 MPa; temperature, 120 °C; time, 1 h. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 XRD patterns of the (a) fresh and (b) used Ru/HAP catalysts. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 (a) NH3- TPD and (b) CO2-TPD profiles of the bare HAP support. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 TEM images and the corresponding particle-size distribution of the (a) fresh and (b) used Ru/HAP catalysts. Table 4 Acidic sites (μmol g−1) Specific acidity (μmol m−2) Basic sites (μmol g−1) Specific basidity (μmol m−2) Total Weak (Brønsted) Medium (Lewis) Strong (Lewis) Total Weak (Brønsted) Medium (Lewis) Strong (Brønsted) 430 290 (67%) 56 (13%) 84 (20%) 8.4 99 77 (78%) 14 (14%) 8 (8%) 1.9 Highly dispersed ruthenium nanoparticles on hydroxyapatite as selective and reusable catalyst for aerobic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid under base-free conditions Tianyu Gao Yongxuan Yin Wenhao Fang ⁎ Qiue Cao School of Chemical Science and Technology, Key Laboratory of Medicinal Chemistry for Natural Resource – Ministry of Education, Functional Molecules Analysis and Biotransformation Key Laboratory of Universities in Yunnan Province, Yunnan University, 2 North Cuihu Road, 650091 Kunming, China School of Chemical Science and Technology Key Laboratory of Medicinal Chemistry for Natural Resource – Ministry of Education Functional Molecules Analysis and Biotransformation Key Laboratory of Universities in Yunnan Province Yunnan University 2 North Cuihu Road Kunming 650091 China ⁎ Corresponding author Graphical abstract The aerobic oxidation of bio-platform compound 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to value-added 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) was studied over hydroxyapatite supported ruthenium (Ru/HAP) nanocatalyst without extra addition of soluble base. Molecular oxygen and water were used as the oxidant and solvent, respectively. Various dominant reaction parameters, including HMF/Ru molar ratio, O2 pressure, reaction temperature and reaction time were systematically investigated. When HMF/Ru molar ratio was of 25, Ru/HAP catalyst exhibited the optimal catalytic performance, i.e., total conversion of HMF and 99.6% yield of FDCA were achieved at 120 °C and 1 MPa O2. Kinetic study revealed that the oxidation of HMF to FDCA followed a tandem pathway and the oxidation of carbonyl group in 5-formylfuran-2-carboxylic acid (FFCA) was found as the rate-determining step. Besides, well-dispersed uniformly-small metallic Ru0 nanoparticles and the acidic-basic sites presented on HAP surface were both essential to drive this base-free oxidation process. During the kinetic-controlled range (i.e., initial 1 h of reaction), the activity of the catalyst can be almost remained after five consecutive cycles; afterwards a minor decline in activity was observed mainly due to the partial oxidation of surface metallic Ru species, but the activity can be entirely recovered by a hydrogen reduction at 350 °C. Keywords 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural Aerobic oxidation Base-free Ruthenium nanoparticles Heterogeneous catalysis 1 Introduction Due to the depletion of fossil fuels and the associated deterioration of world environment, more and more attention has been paid to the valorization of biomass resources for sustainable production of fuels and chemicals [1,2]. Direct conversion of reactive biomass-derived platform instead of lignocellulosic biomass is regarded as a more effective and desirable strategy in the current stage of biorefinery [3]. 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), a dehydration product of fructose and glucose is widely considered as an important and versatile bio-platform compound that can be converted into a variety of value-added chemicals [4–6]. Among those, 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) has received significant attention because FDCA can be used as a renewable bio-monomer in polymer industry, to potentially replace the petro-based terephthalic acid for the production of polyethylene terephthalate (PET) plastic and polybutyleneterephthalate (PBT) plastic [7]. As a furan derivate bearing a hydroxymethyl group and an aldehyde group, HMF can be oxidized to several possible products, such as 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF), 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA), 5-formyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (FFCA), and final product FDCA (Scheme 1 ). There is no doubt that developing selective and productive catalyst for FDCA production remains central in the oxidative valorization of HMF compound [8–10]. In homogenous catalysts, stoichiometric oxidants like KMnO4 [11] and metal halides like Co(OAc)2/Zn(OAc)2/NaBr [12] were employed for oxidation of HMF to FDCA. Acetic acid was needed as solvent for the latter system. But unfortunately only a moderate FDCA yield (ca. 60%) was obtained. In such a context, those homogeneous catalytic systems may generally result in problems of reactor corrosion, toxicity emission and catalyst recycling. Alternatively, heterogeneous catalytic systems for the selective oxidation of HMF to FDCA using supported noble metals (e.g. Au [13,14], Pt [15,16], Pd [17,18] and Ru [19,20]) as active components and molecular oxygen as oxidant were well developed. However, the addition of excessive amount of soluble bases (most often like NaOH or Na2CO3) was prerequisite to achieve high FDCA yield, as it was shown that alkali can facilitate alkoxide formation and CH activation in alcohol oxidation process. As a result, further acidification and purification were needed for subsequent use of FDCA in the polymer industry, hampering the green footprint of the process. Therefore, some recent efforts have been made to perform the base-free aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA using supported noble-metal nanoparticles. And developing low-cost and novel catalyst remains still significant challenge. In supported catalysts the properties of support materials and the interactions between active components and support play a critical role in determining the final catalytic performances of the catalysts. Natural or synthetic acidic-basic minerals such as hydrotalcite (HT) [21–29] and hydroxyapatite (HAP) [30,31] have been successfully employed as catalyst supports for the base-free oxidation of liquid alcohols, especially HT and its derivatives are recently studied for HMF oxidation [23,26–29]. Particularly HAP with the general formula Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2 is the most stable calcium phosphate salt bearing both acidic and basic sites in a single crystal lattice. The tunable Ca/P ratio in HAP material is commonly used as an index for the (non-)stoichiometry composition and strongly affects the acidic-basic properties [32–34]. This makes HAP really attractive to be exploited as an alternative catalyst support for HMF oxidation under base-free conditions. Previously there was only one report showing that HAP encapsulated iron oxide with surface modification by ruthenium (γ-Fe2O3@HAP-Ru) could oxidize HMF, but the major product was 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF) with a yield of 89% [35]. On the other hand, ruthenium is less expensive than other noble metals, even though Pd [27,28], Au [29,36,37] and Pt [38,39] have been largely reported for HMF oxidation. In the point view of low-cost effectiveness, ruthenium catalysts are certainly worth of exploring and the so-far reported catalyst candidates are limited. Liu’s group reported that an activated carbon supported ruthenium (Ru/C) catalyst in the presence of HT as a solid base afforded a FDCA selectivity of 78.2% [19]. Moreover, the yield of FDCA was enhanced up to 97.3% by the 5 wt% Ru/C catalyst but only in the presence of Mg(OH)2 as base additive [40]. In the meantime, commercial Ru/C catalyst [41] and Ru clusters supported on covalent triazine frameworks (Ru/CTFs) [42] were reported as stable catalysts for the oxidation of HMF under base-free conditions. But those catalysts did not exhibit excellent catalytic activity, as the yield of FDCA was of 88% and 78%, respectively. Very recently, MnCo2O4 spinel supported ruthenium (Ru/MnCo2O4) catalyst was reported to afford an enhanced FDCA yield (99%) due to both Lewis and Brønsted acidic sites on the catalyst surface [43]. Nevertheless, the high Ru loading (4 wt%) of catalyst and the high pressure (2.4 MPa air) of oxidant were required to achieve the high FDCA yield. Herein we report highly dispersed and small (ca. 1.8 nm) ruthenium nanoparticles loaded on the cheap and easily available commercial hydroxyapatite as highly selective and stable heterogeneous catalyst for the aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA under base-free conditions. To the best of our knowledge, there has been no report so far on the use of HAP supported Ru nanoparticles (1.5 wt% Ru/HAP) as catalyst in HMF oxidation. The acidic and basic properties of HAP, the morphology and valence state of Ru nanoparticles were carefully characterized. The influence of various reaction parameters (such as HMF/Ru molar ratio, O2 pressure and reaction temperature) and kinetic study were investigated, allowing discussing the plausible reaction mechanism for the oxidative conversion of HMF to FDCA over the Ru/HAP catalyst. Besides, the catalyst stability and reusability were also studied. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and reagents Hydroxyapatite (Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2 34–40% Ca), RuCl3⋅xH2O (≥38% on Ru basis) and NaBH4 ( > 98%) were purchased from Alfa Aesar. Polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, >98%, MW = 10,000) was purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry Co. Ltd. 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF, 98%), 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF, 98%), 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA, 98%), 5-formylfuran-2-carboxylic acid (FFCA, 98%) and 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA, 98%) were purchased from Ark Pharm. All the chemicals were used as received without further purification or treatment. 2.2 Catalyst preparation RuCl3⋅xH2O precursor was dispersed in a polyvinylpyrrolidone aqueous solution (PVP/Ru = 1.2/1, in wt.) under stirring and then a freshly made NaBH4 solution (NaBH4/Ru = 5/1, in mol.) was added dropwise to yield Ru nano-colloidal. Hydroxyapatite water-suspension was added and the mixture was stirred for 2 h under room temperature. The solid was recovered by filtration and washed with hot deionized water (90 °C) to remove PVP and with excessive deionized water to remove Na+ and Cl− ions. The Ru/HAP catalyst was finally dried at 60 °C under vacuum for 12 h. In this work, the theoretical Ru loadings of Ru/HAP catalyst was 1.5 wt%. 2.3 Catalytic reaction HMF (2 mmol) and catalyst (HMF/Ru = 25, in mol.) were added into a batch-type Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave (50 mL) with 20 mL deionized water as solvent. After the introduction of O2 (1 MPa), the reactor was placed in an oil bath pre-heated at 120 °C with magnetic stirring at 600 rpm. After 24 h, the reactor was transferred to ice-bath. Then the catalyst was separated by centrifugation (8000 rmp for 10 min) and washed by deionized water three times followed by drying at 60 °C under vacuum for 12 h before its next use. The liquid sample was analyzed on an Agilent 1260 Infinity high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) with a photodiode array detector (DAD) and a Shodex SH-1011 sugar column (8 mm × 300 mm × 6 μm) using H2SO4 solution (5 mM) as mobile phase. The quantification was carried out using the external standard method. HMF, DFF, HMFCA, FFCA and FDCA were calibrated by using its standard at different concentrations at the specific wavelength (260 nm for HMFCA and FDCA, 285 nm for HMF, and 290 nm for DFF and FFCA). The conversion of HMF and the selectivity of each product were defined as the molar percentage of HMF converted and the molar percentage of each product formed in HMF converted, thus the yield of each product can be calculated. Both conversion and selectivity were calculated on a carbon basis. Each reaction was repeated twice at least to guarantee a reproducible result. C o n v e r s i o n = n HMF , i n i t i a l − n HMF , f i n a l n H M F , i n i t i a l × 100 % S e l e c t i v i t y = n p r o d u c t n H M F , c o n v e r t e d × 100 % Y i e l d = n product n HMF , i n i t i a l × 100 % 2.4 Characterizations The Ru loading was analyzed by Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS) technique using an Agilent 7500a apparatus. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was carried out on a Rigaku TTR III Diffractometer provided with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) and a beam voltage of 40 kV. The patterns were registered in the 2θ domain (5−90°) with a measured step of 0.02° and a time integration of 0.2 s. The textural properties were measured by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77 K on a Quadrasorb evo ™ Surface Area and Pore Size Analyzer. The specific surface areas were calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The pore volume and the pore size were calculated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Prior to the sorption measurements, the samples were degassed at 150 °C for 3 h. NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was carried out on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 analyzer. The sample (20 mg) loaded in a quartz reactor was pretreated with helium at 300 °C for 1 h. After cooling to 30 °C, NH3 adsorption was performed by switching helium to a 10% NH3-90% He (in vol.) mixed gas and then maintaining for 1 h. The gas-phase NH3 was purged by helium at the same temperature. NH3-TPD was then performed in helium flow by raising the temperature to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1. The desorbed NH3 was detected on a ThermoStar GSD 301 T2 mass spectrometer at the signal of m/z 17. This protocol is also applicable to CO2-TPD. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) measurement was carried out on a Philips-FEI TECNAI F30 field emission electron microscope. Acceleration voltage was 300 kV. Samples were suspended in ethanol and dispersed ultrasonically. Drops of the suspension were applied on a lacey support film. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was carried out on a Thermo Scientific Escalab 250 Xi system provided with Al Kα radiation under ultra-high vacuum. The binding energy shift due to the surface charging was adjusted using a reference to the C 1s line at 284.5 eV. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Optimization of reaction parameters for the oxidation of HMF to FDCA In this section, the dominant reaction parameters including HMF/Ru molar ratio, O2 pressure and reaction temperature were investigated. The objective was to find the optimized reaction conditions for HMF oxidation over the Ru/HAP catalyst and disclose how each parameter influences the distribution of products, as well as the conversion of HMF. 3.1.1 Effect of HMF/Ru molar ratio The molar ratio of HMF to the active components (i.e., HMF/Ru in the work) is believed as an important factor in the oxidation of HMF to FDCA. As shown in Fig. 1 , both the conversion of HMF and yield of FDCA, by using a HMF/Ru molar ratio of 25, achieve already complete. In order to investigate whether the bare support contributes to the catalytic activity for the oxidation of HMF, the parent HAP is used as the referenced catalyst. In such a case, no HMF can be converted. This confirms that the presence of Ru species is very essential to activate HMF and to achieve high conversion and selectivity of HMF and FDCA, respectively. When the ratio increases from 25 to 60, i.e., more substrate is introduced, the conversion of HMF is found a gradual decrease, but the yield of products varies in a different manner, suggesting a multistep reaction pathway. It can be seen that the distribution of products is dependent on the molar ratio of HMF to Ru. By decreasing the ratio from 60 to 40, the yield of FFCA and FDCA undergoes a slow increase, but when HMF/Ru molar ratio further decreases from 40 to 25, the yield of FDCA is found a major increase, instead, the yield of FFCA largely declines. During the wholly investigated parameter domain, the yield of other intermediates (i.e., DFF and HMFCA) shows slow and minor change. This body of results shows that oxidative conversion of HMF to FDCA is a tandem reaction, following several intermediate steps, of which FFCA to FDCA seems a slow and difficult step that requires an adequate amount of active Ru species. 3.1.2 Effect of oxygen pressure The influence of O2 pressure on the oxidation of HMF to FDCA over Ru/HAP catalyst is plotted in Fig. 2 . The O2 pressure is investigated in the range of 0.2–1 MPa. At a near ambient pressure (0.2 MPa), the conversion of HMF attains 100%, while the yield of FDCA is of 25%. FFCA (75% in yield) is the only byproduct detected. This shows that HMF, as well as the oxidized intermediates (i.e., DFF and HMFCA), are oxidized quickly and already completely converted under a low O2 pressure. However, the further conversion of FFCA to FDCA is incomplete and seems to require more oxidant. By increasing the O2 pressure from 0.2 to 1 MPa, the conversion of HMF maintains complete, but the yield of FDCA increases almost linearly. In the meantime, the yield of FFCA is found decreasing significantly, following a reverse evolution of FDCA. Thereby, it can be seen that oxidizing FFCA to FDCA on the Ru/HAP catalyst is rather sensitive to the variation of O2 pressure. Total conversion of HMF and >99% yield of FDCA are obtained when 1 MPa O2 is applied to the catalytic system. 3.1.3 Effect of reaction temperature Fig. 3 shows the dependence of the conversion of HMF and yield of products on reaction temperature. It is interesting to observe that during the investigated temperature domain (60–120 °C), only FFCA as the intermediate byproduct can be measured. This indicates that even at a mild temperature (e.g. 60 °C) the Ru/HAP catalyst is capable of effectively converting the oxidized intermediates including DFF and HMFCA to FFCA as soon as they are derived from HMF, whereas the subsequent oxidation of FFCA to FDCA is obviously difficult. When the reaction temperature goes up from 60 to 120 °C, the conversion of HMF increases gradually while the yield of FDCA increases more intensely, and this corresponds to a so-expected decline of the formation of FFCA. Total conversion of HMF and >99% yield of FDCA are obtained at 120 °C. It thus can be disclosed that higher reaction temperature is essential to promote the conversion of HMF. Particularly the oxidation of FFCA to FDCA is strongly dependent on the reaction temperature employed. All the above results raise one’s interest in the reaction pathway of HMF to FDCA over the Ru/HAP catalyst, which could probably help elucidate the relationship of catalyst properties and its performances. 3.2 Kinetic study on the oxidation of HMF to FDCA The time course analysis for the conversion of HMF and the yield of products is reported in Fig. 4 . The data is obtained by discontinuous experiments, i.e., one reading per experiment for each reaction time. The conversion of HMF increases rapidly up to 100% in the initial 4 h. The yield of HMFCA and DFF reaches 2% and 18% within the initial 1 h respectively, and then turns to decrease quickly as the time continues. Finally HMFCA and DFF vanish at 4 h and 6 h, respectively. The yield of FFCA increases already to 62% within the initial 4 h and starts to decrease afterwards. FFCA is found as the only byproduct after 6 h of reaction. In contrast to FFCA, the yield of FDCA increases almost monotonically with reaction time and achieves 99.6% after 24 h, remaining trace (<0.4%) production of FFCA in the catalytic system. These observations confirm a tandem pathway for the oxidation of HMF to FDCA via DFF and HMFCA followed by FFCA to FDCA over the Ru/HAP catalyst (as shown in Scheme 1). Formation of FFCA from DFF and HMFCA is found really fast but the subsequent conversion of FFCA to FDCA appears much slower. In order to gain further insight into the reaction pathway of HMF to FDCA over the Ru/HAP catalyst, HMF and every single intermediate are used as the reactant to perform kinetic experiments. In order to see the true reaction rate of each step, the time course tests are conducted within the initial reaction stage for 1 h and the molar ratio of substrate to Ru is doubled to 50. The obtained curves are plotted in Fig. 5 and the initial reaction rate of the intermediates corresponding to each oxidation step is calculated and listed in Table 1 . As shown in Fig. 5, the formation of DFF and HMFCA are observed in the initial stage of reaction, which confirms the simultaneous oxidation of the hydroxyl group and the carbonyl group in HMF over the Ru/HAP catalyst. The yield of DFF is constantly higher than that of HMFCA even if they follow the same evolution. This suggests that oxidation of the hydroxyl group in HMF to carbonyl group is faster than that of the carbonyl group. The generation of both DFF and HMFCA becomes clearly slow after 20 min, while FFCA formation increases significantly. The subsequent conversion of DFF and HMFCA to FFCA is found different, respectively. The calculation reveals that the reaction rate of DFF to FFCA (211 μmol molRu −1 min−1) is more than two folds of HMFCA (93 μmol molRu −1 min−1). This reveals that oxidation of the carbonyl group in DFF to the carboxyl group in FFCA is faster than the oxidation of hydroxyl group in HMFCA to carbonyl group in FFCA. The last oxidative step of FFCA to FDCA is found the slowest with a rate of 8 μmol molRu −1 min−1, revealing that the oxidation of the aldehyde group in FFCA to carboxyl group in FDCA is the rate-determining step. The detailed kinetic study demonstrates that the aerobic oxidation of HMF on the Ru/HAP catalyst follows a parallel reaction pathway, i.e., oxidation of the hydroxyl group and the carbonyl group in HMF co-occurs, but the former route is dominant. Moreover, it can be inspired that boosting the activation and transformation of the carbonyl group in FFCA plays a key role in enhancing the efficiency of Ru-based catalyst, as also concluded on activated carbon supported Ru (Ru/C) catalysts [40,41]. 3.3 Comparison of FDCA productivity on Ru-based benchmark catalysts Table 2 compares the catalytic performance of the Ru/HAP catalyst developed in this work to the so-far reported Ru-based benchmark catalysts, including organic frameworks supported Ru (Entry 1), oxides supported Ru (Entry 2&3), and activated carbon supported Ru (Entry 4), which have been recently reported for HMF oxidation to FDCA under base-free conditions. First of all, conversion of HMF (100%) with Ru/HAP is the same as all the other benchmark catalysts. Whereas the yield of FDCA (99.6%) is found the highest among all the referenced catalysts even if Ru/MnCo2O4 also afforded high FDCA yield of 99.1%. As a matter of fact, it is difficult to compare the activities between different catalytic systems when different reaction conditions are used, in particular the molar ratios of HMF to Ru, reaction times and temperatures are varied. Therefore, in order to provide a simplified and also straightforward measure, the productivity in the form of molFDCA molRu −1 h−1 for a catalyst that quantifies the specific activity of each single catalytic center for the production of FDCA can be defined. In such a case, the true activity of a catalyst may be roughly compared, but the influence of reaction temperature and oxidant pressure cannot be underestimated. Ru/CTFs catalyst affords the highest FDCA productivity of 10.3 molFDCA molRu −1 h−1 but working at 140 °C and 2.0 MPa air. To be recalled, it has been shown that higher temperature and higher oxidant pressure could kinetically promote the yield of FDCA [8]. The rest catalysts provide comparable FDCA productivities in the same order, of which Ru/MnCo2O4 shows a relatively higher value (3.3 molFDCA molRu −1 h−1). Still, a high air pressure of 2.4 MPa is compromised in this case. Besides, the dilution of HMF in solvent is believed to probably impact the activity [36,44]. In industry, it is desired and cost-effective to convert concentrated HMF to FDCA. The developed Ru/HAP catalyst (Entry 5) demonstrates an average and similar FDCA productivity (1.0 molFDCA molRu −1 h−1) compared to Ru(OH) x /CeO2 and Ru/C benchmark catalysts. Among all the reported Ru-catalyzed base-free HMF oxidations, only Ru/MnCo2O4 catalyst, in addition to our Ru/HAP catalyst, can lead to the stoichiometric FDCA production. This is of high importance for separation and purification in industrial application even if the efficiency of the catalyst should be taken into account. On the other hand, the activity of the Ru/HAP is obtained at a lower reaction temperature and a lower pressure of gaseous oxygen. Thus a higher FDCA productivity might be expected when the harder reaction conditions (e.g. higher temperature and/or O2 pressure) are employed. It is shown by experiment (Entry 6) that a FDCA productivity as high as 4.0 molFDCA molRu −1 h−1 can be obtained on the Ru/HAP catalyst by simply increasing reaction temperature to 140 °C. By doing this, more substrate (HMF/Ru molar ratio: 75) are converted into FDCA within shorter time (18 h). Besides, one should mention that a commercial HAP is used in the present work, but in fact the surface acidic-basic properties of HAP material can be rationally tuned by varying the Ca/P ratio or by replacing Ca2+ ions by vacancies or cations such as Sr2+, Mg2+, Na+ and K+, which would potentially ameliorate the productivity of FDCA using the same formulation of Ru/HAP catalyst. Therefore, Ru/HAP is still very competitive and promising catalyst candidate that will be studied in depth in our laboratory in the future. With respect to the catalytic stability, all the above mentioned catalysts can be reused for about five times. 3.4 Catalyst stability and reusability The stability and recycling ability are regarded as very important properties for any heterogeneous catalyst. The Ru/HAP catalyst demonstrates a good stability under the optimized reaction conditions during a consecutive recycling (Fig. 6 a). A minor activity loss (≤5%) is observed in both HMF conversion and FDCA selectivity, leading approximately to an overall 10% loss in yield of FDCA after the fifth cycle. In order to see the rational stability of the Ru/HAP catalyst, the recycling test is further conducted within the kinetic-controlled region, i.e., the initial reaction stage for 1 h where the conversion rate of HMF stays around 150 μmol molRu −1 min−1 and the true catalytic activity can be measured. The catalyst is reused after post-treatment (i.e., centrifugation, water-washing and vacuum-drying at 60 °C, respectively) for the consecutive reactions. As displayed in Fig. 6b, the catalyst exhibits a relatively good stability during the first three cycles but it continues to gradually loss activity up to the seventh cycle (ca. 12% reduction of activity). However, the oxidation of HMF is a much easier step compared to the oxidation of FFCA to FDCA, i.e., the rate-controlled step. To be rigorous, the initial reaction rate of FFCA is also monitored. It can be clearly seen that the Ru/HAP catalyst shows a quick deactivation in FFCA transformation after the third cycle and becomes relatively stable from the fifth cycle with ca. 25% of activity lost. This observation suggests that the kinetic deactivation behavior of the Ru/HAP may be mainly due to the activity loss during the oxidation of FFCA to FDCA. In order to verify the possible reason for activity loss, various characterizations on the used catalyst is performed. The detailed results are reported in the following characterization section. In general, no leaching of Ru species, as well as Ca species from HAP, in the aqueous reaction mixture is detected by ICP-MS technique. Besides, XRD analysis shows that the used catalyst well maintains the crystalline phase of HAP. Moreover, TEM images clearly confirm no aggregation of Ru nanoparticles which are still highly dispersed on HAP surface after several tests. Thereby, it can be probably assumed that the activity loss may be due to the partial oxidation of surface Ru nanoparticles. To verify the hypothesis, a reduction treatment of the used catalyst in H2 at 350 °C for 4 h is applied. And the catalytic activity of Ru/HAP is entirely recovered (Fig. 6b). This may partially confirm that the presence of Ru cations due to the oxidation of surface metallic Ru during continuous recycling tests could lead to some activity loss of the catalyst. To be rigorous, the fresh Ru/HAP catalyst is calcined in an air flow at 350 °C for 4 h to form Ruδ+/HAP solid. This catalyst affords ca. 80% HMF conversion but with a significantly lower yield of FDCA (<10%) compared to the Ru0/HAP catalyst under the same conditions. It thus confirms that metallic Ru species is indispensable to the oxidation of HMF, especially important for oxidation of FFCA to FDCA. However, one should mention that the adsorbed impurities on the catalyst surface (most often being difficult in identifying) may also result in activity loss. As a matter of fact, it was reported such a poison on supported Ru nanocatalyst during HMF oxidation can be overcome by reactivation in H2 [19] or washing with DMSO [42]. 3.5 Characterizations of catalyst 3.5.1 Composition and structure The precise Ru loading measured by the Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS) is of 1.5 wt% (Table 3 ), which appears the same as the theoretical value used for preparation, showing an effective immobilization of Ru species on HAP following the employed protocol. The specific surface area of HAP measured by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms is of 51 m2 g−1, and the pore volume and pore size are of 0.3 cm3 g−1 and 30.3 nm, respectively. These values are hardly varied after loading Ru particles. Fig. 7 shows the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the fresh and used Ru/HAP catalysts. Both samples display the same diffraction patterns. A series of well crystallized diffraction peaks are present at 2θ value of 25.9°, 32°, 33.2°, 40.1°, 46.9° and 49.6°, which are assigned to the (002), (211), (300), (130), (222) and (213) planes of crystalline hydroxyapatite phase according to the JCPDS 01-084-1998 index. It is obvious that the structure of catalyst is well maintained after reaction, showing a stable calcium phosphate structure of HAP. There is no overlap of the HAP lines to the Ru main lines. In fact, no diffraction peak due to Ru species is detected whatever before or after reaction, probably owning to the low Ru loading and the small diameter of Ru nanoparticles. The Ca/P ratio is an important parameter for HAP materials, which is commonly used as an index of the stoichiometry composition and of their acidic-basic properties. It is well known that HAP materials behave as solid acid catalysts when the Ca/P equals 1.50, and exhibit both the acidic and basic characteristics when the Ca/P ratio is between 1.50 and 1.67. The Ca/P atomic ratio measured by ICP-MS for the commercial HAP used in this work is of 1.65 (as listed in Table 3), which is in agreement with the stoichiometric composition of HAP (Ca/P: 1.67). Concerning the Ca/P ratio, the XPS surface analysis is slightly lower than the XRD bulk analysis, suggesting that Ca species are less exposed to the surface than phosphates, at least within the approximately 10 nm analysis depth limit of the XPS technique. This phenomenon is in agreement with the previous observation on distribution of Ca and P in HAP materials [32]. Besides, a series of quite similar Ca/P ratios are obtained on the used catalyst, indicating not only the highly similar composition but also the similar acidic-basic properties may be retained. 3.5.2 Surface acidity and basicity of HAP The surface acidity and basicity of the HAP support are determined by the temperature-programmed desorption technique using gaseous NH3 and CO2 as proble molecule, respectively. The strength of acid sites is directly related to the desorption temperature. Generally for the sake of analysis, NH3 is desorbed from weak acid sites below 300 °C, from medium acid sites between 350 and 500 °C, and from strong acid sites between 500 and 650 °C [45]. As shown in Fig. 8 , the NH3-TPD profile of HAP yields three deconvoluted peaks loacted at ca. 160, 430 and 570 °C, respectively. The corresponding acid sites can be attributed to HPO4 2− anions, OH− vacancies (δ +), and Ca2+ cations present on HAP surface, respectively [32,45]. Hence, in the commercial HAP support HPO4 2− anions act as Brønsted acid sites while Ca2+ and vacancies as Lewis acid sites. The total acidity in HAP is measured by integrating the NH3-TPD profile, and then the specific acidity and the acidity derived from different sites are deduced and gathered in Table 4 . The specific acidity is of 8.4 μmol m−2. The sum of weak and medium acid sites reaches 80% of the total acidity, and the Brønsted acid sites (67% in total) are dominant. Similarly the CO2-TPD profile of HAP leads to three distinguished peaks loacted at ca. 180, 290 and 490 °C corresponding to the weak, medium and strong basic sites, respectively. The weak and medium basic sites can be due to the contribution of PO4 3− anions and CaO species (i.e., O2− anions) respectively, while the strong sites can be attributed to OH− groups [32,33,46]. The specific basicity of HAP is of 1.9 μmol m−2 that appears less than four folds of acidity. The main contribution to the surface basicity are due to the weak and medium basic sites (92% in total), and the Brønsted basic sites (86% in total) are also dominant. 3.5.3 Morphology and dispersion The grain shape of HAP and the morphology of Ru nanoparticles are shown in Fig. 9 from the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images. Typical rod-shaped agglomerates are observed for the fresh Ru/HAP catalyst and this grain shape is well maintained after test, in agreement with the XRD results. Nanoparticulated Ru species are clearly found highly dispersed on the HAP surface and the mean size of Ru nanoparticles is measured of 1.8 ± 0.2 nm. Moreover, the distribution of particle size is found in a narrow domain between 0.5 and 2.5 nm. In such a case, the dispersion of Ru particles can be discussed. By assuming a spherical model of Ru nanoparticles, a universal mathematical relation between the mean relative size of metallic crystallites (d rel(VS)) and their dispersion (FE) in supported metal catalysts can be developed [45]. Thus the dispersion of Ru particles can be estimated by adapting the TEM data to the mathematical formula reported in the literature. A dispersion of ca. 60% to Ru nanoparticles is calculated, which corresponds to a high dispersion of catalytically active Ru species that are responsible for the high productivity of FDCA under mild reaction conditions. After reaction Ru nanoparticles are found strongly resistant to any aggregation, and very uniform and small Ru species in nanoparticles are still well present. This suggests that strong metal-support interactions may exist between Ru nanoparticles and HAP. 3.5.4 Valence state of surface Ru species The valence state of Ru nanoparticles on HAP measured by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is reported in Fig. 10 . The Ru 3p orbital level is analyzed due to an overlap between Ru 3d and C 1 s regions. The fresh catalyst shows a characteristic peak centered at ca. 462.5 eV, which is assigned to the typical metallic Ru0 species [43]. However, a small amount (≤5%) of oxidized Ruδ+ species is found on catalyst surface. As a matter of fact, a Ru catalyst handled in air can be slightly oxidized at the surface [19,40]. The used catalyst after the fifth cycle presents an obviously asymmetric and wider peak, and a higher proportion (17%) of cationic Ru species due to non-stoichiometric RuO x (Ruδ+) [47] and/or RuO2 (Ru4+) [19] are emerged on surface in addition to the Ru0 species. This oxidized surface Ruδ+ species are largely reported as the reason responsible for the activity loss of supported Ru catalysts for the aerobic oxidation of HMF [19,41,43]. Accordingly, reductive treatment with H2 is the common strategy to regenerate the active components. 3.6 Discussion on the plausible reaction mechanism Based upon the above experimental results and the reported work regarding selective oxidation of alcohols and aldehydes over supported metal nanoparticles and the function of acidic-basic supports [24,27,30,43,48], the plausible reaction mechanism of aerobic oxidation of HMF over the Ru/HAP catalyst could be discussed. The major reaction pathway via DFF, selected as an illustrative example, is proposed in Scheme 2 . Kinetic study in the present work shows that DFF is the main intermediate in the first oxidation step even if HMFCA is simultaneously generated. Formation of DFF and subsequent oxidation to FFCA occur much faster than the oxidation of FFCA to FDCA, which reveals that conversion of FFCA to FDCA is the rate-limiting step. The mechanism of primary alcohol oxidation to aldehyde over a supported metal catalyst likely begins with the formation of a metal alkoxide [48]. The basic sites of the HAP support might act to cleave the OH bond of HMF molecule to form a Ru-alkoxide intermediate [24,27]. It was proposed by the isotopic tracing experiments that the aerobic oxidation of HMF to FFCA followed a Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism involving the dissociative adsorption of both HMF and O2 molecules to form the adsorbed alcoholate and atomic oxygen species on the Ru/C catalyst, and subsequent kinetically relevant abstraction of β-hydride from the alcoholate species via the active atomic oxygen species on Ru0 surface [19]. β-Hydride elimination is widely accepted as the pivotal step for oxidation of alcohols and aldehydes over metal catalysts, to yield a carbonyl group and a carboxylic group respectively, as well as a metal-hydride [25,48]. Catalytically active metal atoms are more effective for the cleavage of this CH bond [30]. Thus surface metallic Ru0 species are critical to activate oxygen molecule and to promote conversion of FFCA. In addition to that, it might be speculated that the acidic sites on the HAP support might participate in oxidizing the Ru-hydride to produce a water molecule and one half of an oxygen molecule [30], even though no direct information is currently obtained. As a matter of fact, it was reported recently that both Brønsted and Lewis acidic active sites of the MnCo2O4 support in Ru/MnCo2O4 catalyst were shown essential to greatly enhance the FDCA yield [43]. On the other hand, it is generally accepted that the presence of basic sites on catalysts could promote the oxidation of −CHO group to −COOH group [24,29,48]. Thereby it is reasonable to observe, on a lower number of specific basic sites, a nucleophilic addition of a hydroxyl group on HAP to the aldehyde group of HMF, and then a carboxylic group is generated through a dehydrogenation reaction of the newly formed hydroxyl group on active Ru0 sites. The basic sites react with adsorbed FFCA, facilitating desorption and the recovery of the active Ru0 species [27,28]. It was believed that O2 reacted as an electron scavenger and would clean the surface of metallic noble metals by forming peroxide and water to close the catalytic cycle [30,49]. However, as the active surface Ru0 species are partially oxidized with the time on stream, it becomes more difficult for O2 molecules to dissociate on Ru nanoparticles, leading to a deficient activation of the OH bond in HMF. Thus a H2 treatment could regenerate the activity of the Ru/HAP catalyst. 4 Conclusions It was reported for the first time that hydroxyapatite supported highly dispersed ruthenium nanoparticles can selectively catalyze the aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA in water with no need of extra base additives under mild conditions. Almost stoichiometric yield (99.6%) of FDCA was obtained. The enhanced yield of FDCA was attributed to the availability of both acidic and basic sites on the surface of HAP support, and highly dispersed (60% dispersion) surface metallic Ru0 nanoparticles with uniform and small size (d = 1.8 nm). Such metallic Ru species were confirmed in strong resistance to aggregation during reaction. The kinetic study revealed that HMF oxidation over the Ru/HAP catalyst underwent a parallel reaction pathway via transition-state DFF and HMFCA followed by FFCA to FDCA. The oxidation of −OH group in HMF to −CHO group in DFF was the fastest step whereas the oxidation of CHO group in FFCA to COOH group in FDCA was the slowest rate-limiting step. Heterogeneous Ru/HAP catalyst was found reusable with a gentle activity loss mainly due to the partial oxidation of surface Ru0 species which resulted in the deactivation for conversion of FFCA to FDCA, but the activity can be fully recovered with a H2 treatment. coredata.dc:description: The aerobic oxidation of bio-platform compound 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to value-added 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) was studied over hydroxyapatite supported ruthenium (Ru/HAP) nanocatalyst without extra addition of soluble base. Molecular oxygen and water were used as the oxidant and solvent, respectively. Various dominant reaction parameters, including HMF/Ru molar ratio, O2 pressure, reaction temperature and reaction time were systematically investigated. When HMF/Ru molar ratio was of 25, Ru/HAP catalyst exhibited the optimal catalytic performance, i.e., total conversion of HMF and 99.6% yield of FDCA were achieved at 120 °C and 1 MPa O2. Kinetic study revealed that the oxidation of HMF to FDCA followed a tandem pathway and the oxidation of carbonyl group in 5-formylfuran-2-carboxylic acid (FFCA) was found as the rate-determining step. Besides, well-dispersed uniformly-small metallic Ru0 nanoparticles and the acidic-basic sites presented on HAP surface were both essential to drive this base-free oxidation process. During the kinetic-controlled range (i.e., initial 1 h of reaction), the activity of the catalyst can be almost remained after five consecutive cycles; afterwards a minor decline in activity was observed mainly due to the partial oxidation of surface metallic Ru species, but the activity can be entirely recovered by a hydrogen reduction at 350 °C.
coredata.dc:title: Highly dispersed ruthenium nanoparticles on hydroxyapatite as selective and reusable catalyst for aerobic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid under base-free conditions
